executive_summary: Fine arts schools enjoyed solid revenue growth in the years leading up to the pandemic as spending on leisure activities and disposable income were on the rise. When the COVID-19 pandemic began to spread, though, fine arts schools were forced to contend with plummeting enrollment as lockdowns prevented social gathering and skyrocketing unemployment left many unable to partake in their favorite recreational pastimes. As the pandemic began to subside and fine arts schools were once again able to open their doors, attendance returned revenue jumped in 2021 and 2022. This began to offset the massive drop in revenue in 2020, though growth was severely slowed as widespread inflation left many with little disposable income.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The solid growth fine arts schools benefitted from through the early period was entirely undone in 2020 as the COVID-19 pandemic spread and consumers were forced to stay home. As lockdowns lifted and students were able to once again gather together, revenue began to rise again and is expected to reach pre-pandemic levels this year.

Industry-wide revenue has been growing at an annualized 0.6% over the past five years to $7.0 billion. This includes a jump of 4.2% in 2023, when revenue expected to finally surpass pre-pandemic levels.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Industry revenue is largely driven by disposable income
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Industry revenue is largely driven by the ability of everyday consumers to afford fine arts classes as a form of leisure and education. Per capita disposable income steadily increased over the five years to 2023 until a severe downturn in 2022 amid the inflationary atmosphere. Still, fine arts classes have become more affordable to consumers through the period as disposable income has risen.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Federal Funding Drops Will Be Offset By Rising Disposable Income
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Federal funding to creative arts will drop after 2023, challenging fine arts schools that will lose direct subsidies. With falling federal funding, fine arts schools will have no choice but to raise tuition costs, deterring price-sensitive consumers from enrolling. This will slow the industry's growth from the larger yearly swells in revenue experienced after the COVID-19 pandemic, but a steady rise in per capita disposable income will ensure revenue continues to push upward.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Wage Costs Will Continue To Rise
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Per-employee pay fell over the past five years while total wage costs rose, and this trend is expected to stall over the next five years. Fine arts schools need to hire new faculty members to keep instructor-to-student ratios low, raising wage expenses. Per-employee pay dropped in 2020 through COVID-19 challenges but is expected to remain near the current level through the end of 2028.

industry_definition: This industry includes operators that offer instruction in the fine arts, including dance, drama, music and the visual arts. The industry does not include programs that offer academic degrees or diplomas. Commercial and graphic arts and commercial photography instruction are also excluded from this industry, as these subjects are accounted for in the Trade and Technical Schools industry (IBISWorld report 61151).

threats: Time spent on leisure and sports

key_trends: Challenges from COVID-19 have lingered. Volatile disposable income amid inflation and a shaky job market have limited the ability of consumers to return to recreational fine arts classes. Revenue is expected to finally fully recover in 2023.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Consumers between the ages of 25 and 54 are typically working adults that have more disposable income than younger consumers. These students often look to the industry as a place to socialize, and fine arts schools need to offer evening and weekend classes to properly capture demand from these consumers.

Nearly a quarter of revenue comes from students under 25, mostly because of parents enrolling their children in fine arts schools for cognitive and social development. Fine arts schools should offer a range of courses that appeal to students of different experience levels in order to bring in consumers from this group.

Consumers between 55 and 74 are often well-established in a career and have a reliable stream of income. Many adults begin taking fine arts classes after retiring, and an aging population will make elevate this segment over the next five years.

Because many may lack the physical strength to do so, there are very few students over the age of 75. These consumers also often live in senior care communities or retirement homes, so there is little need for the social benefits fine arts schools bring.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment is made up of all dance classes designed for recreation and leisure, including formal performance dances (ballet and modern dance) as well as hip-hop, ballroom dances (the waltz and the tango, jazz dances) and worldwide dances (flamenco, belly dancing and capoeira)

Fine arts schools offer recreational music, theater and musical theater classes, typically available to students of all ages and skill levels. These classes cover many subjects, ranging from the study and performance of classical music and Shakespearean theater to the study of more modern subjects like music production and theater lighting and design.

While most fine arts schools rely on revenue from amateur artists and everyday consumers, many schools also offer training programs and career development courses to professional artists and art major students.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: This segment is made up of all dance classes designed for recreation and leisure, including formal performance dances (ballet and modern dance) as well as hip-hop, ballroom dances (the waltz and the tango, jazz dances) and worldwide dances (flamenco, belly dancing and capoeira). While these classes can vary significantly in terms of style and skill level, students enrolled in these courses are generally amateur dancers with limited formal training. These classes took a hit to attendance through the COVID-19 pandemic but have since rebounded.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Recreational Music and Theater Classes Cover Many Topics
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Fine arts schools offer recreational music, theater and musical theater classes, typically available to students of all ages and skill levels. These classes cover many subjects, ranging from the study and performance of classical music and Shakespearean theater to the study of more modern subjects like music production and theater lighting and design. This segment is expected to expand through the end of 2028 as rising per capita disposable income allows potential students to invest in instruments and begin taking lessons.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Training and Professional Development Programs Help Educate Professionals
demand_determinants.determinant_description: While most fine arts schools rely on revenue from amateur artists and everyday consumers, many schools also offer training programs and career development courses to professional artists and art major students.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Academic Programs Help Supplement the Arts
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This segment represents programs that cater to both gifted and disadvantaged students looking to study specific arts, at times for credits. Fine arts schools offer basic courses as well as advanced deep dives on research in the arts, though these don't always offer certificates or degrees.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Contributions, Recreational Visual Arts Classes and Other Classes are Wide-Ranging
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Fine arts schools also offer many recreational courses for the visual arts, including ceramics, drawing, painting, sculpting and photography classes. Because the fine arts occupy a position of cultural value, the industry can rely on consistent donations from foundations and private individuals.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest percentage of both establishments and population compared to other regions. The percentage of establishments in the Southeast region is around 30%, while the population percentage is slightly lower, around 25%. There are more states in this region than in any other, which means there are many local communities for fine arts schools to serve. This region also has a solid history of the arts, especially in cities like New Orleans and Charleston.

California has more fine arts schools than any other state by a wide margin as Los Angeles is a magnet for talent from all over. This region also has a large population and a cultural focus on the arts, so locals often attend a fine arts school as a hobby.

The third-most-popular region for fine arts schools is the Mid-Atlantic, as its bustling cultural hubs create heightened demand for fine arts schools. New York is home to some of the industry's most famous schools, The Juilliard School and Berklee College of Music.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Title IX prohibits art schools from discriminating by sex or gender identity.
The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act ensures students with disabilities have access to education and reasonable accommodations.
Degree- or certificate-granting fine arts schools need to be accredited, usually by a subsidiary of the National Office for Arts Accreditation.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Fine arts education requires a significant amount of labor-intensive instruction, which can be costly and time-consuming.
From one-on-one critiques to hands-on demonstrations, the faculty-to-student ratio is often high, making it challenging for schools to scale their programs while maintaining quality standards.

basis_points.basis_description: Price is a key competitive base. Consumers usually attend fine arts schools as a hobby, so keeping prices low is the best way to prevent losses in attendance when per capita disposable income falls.

Reputation brings in students. Fine arts schools usually specialize in one specific art, like dance or music, and need to have a solid track record of elevating their student's skills. Some schools accomplish this by having a famous founder.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Fine arts enthusiasts look for schools in their area, so schools naturally need to be distributed in close correlation with population. There are a massive number of potential markets for fine arts schools to serve, and schools don't often buy out competitors.

Each fine arts school generally specializes in one type of art, so there's room for many schools in one market. The industry includes a wide range of certifications and specialties, including photography, dance, music, acting and painting, making it challenging for any.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Having a lower instructor-to-student ratio is essential to providing quality training.
Per-employee pay is not very high and has declined over the past five years.
Total wage expenses have slightly risen as fine arts schools have hired more faculty.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand fluctuates with economic security as attendance is relatively expensive and discretionary.
The reliance on donations of individuals or foundations creates volatility as it depends on corporate profit and disposable income.

FAQs.question: How do you differentiate your fine arts school from your competitors in sales and marketing strategies?
FAQs.answer: Demand is heavily localized for this industry, and aspiring fine arts students typically have access to more than one qualified institution. Fine arts students don't usually need prior experience in the field of study to enroll in industry courses. As a result, students may be of any age and often come from a range of educational backgrounds.

FAQs.question: What is the NGCAE and other trade associations for fine arts schools?
FAQs.answer: Fine arts schools can rely on any of the several industry-specific trade associations that exist to offer support and advice, like the NGCAE. Composed of more than 400 member organizations, the National Association for Music Education and the National Guild for Community Arts Education (NGCAE) provides programs, conferences, information and advocacy to nonprofit, community-based arts schools that don't grant degrees.

FAQs.question: How are improving medical technologies and healthcare affecting demand for fine arts classes?
FAQs.answer: Improving medical technologies and healthcare are helping senior citizens live longer and remain active long after retiring. Some are seeking fine arts classes for recreation.

FAQs.question: With the price of tuition growing and student expectations rising, have you invested in more amenities?
FAQs.answer: To diversify themselves, companies must provide value-added courses and amenities.

FAQs.question: How has your establishment been affected by the socioeconomic dynamics in your area?
FAQs.answer: Different course offerings appeal to various types of people. Costly tuition can deter local students with low disposable income.

FAQs.question: Technology has become increasingly important to fine arts schools for creative development, production and business operations. Have you increased your investment in educational technology?
FAQs.answer: Many fine arts schools are adapting their courses to the current technological environment by offering up-to-date courses on topics like digital art and music production.

FAQs.question: Has uncertainty in some funding programs affected your investment strategy?
FAQs.answer: Declining federal funding has deterred many companies from making larger purchases.

FAQs.question: Do you work with any advocacy groups to advance your establishment's interests?
FAQs.answer: Accreditation bodies support some fine arts schools by providing information on issues relevant to the fine arts community.

FAQs.question: How much do you rely on federal funding?
FAQs.answer: Most smaller fine arts schools don't rely heavily on government funding to remain in business.

FAQs.question: In addition to wages for professors and lecturers, universities require teaching support staff and other staff involved in the upkeep of facilities. How do your wage outlays compare to your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Wages vary significantly based on the geographic location of the school, the educational background of the employee and the difficulty of the course or program.

FAQs.question: How do you deal with long gaps in the year with less funding?
FAQs.answer: Many companies rely on private funding to continue operations during periods of lesser funding.

FAQs.question: Labor costs for fine arts schools are high as the industry is relatively labor-intensive. How reliant is your company on the support of local communities? How do you attract adequate funding and staff?
FAQs.answer: Community and nonprofit organizations operating in this industry will benefit from accessing volunteer labor.

FAQs.question: How do you respond to variability in consumer demand? Are you able to quickly and easily alter the services offered?
FAQs.answer: Successful fine arts schools will be able to alter the type of training offered to suit the varying needs of students and potential students.

FAQs.question: What portion of your revenue comes from this financial aid? How will increased regulation in the future affect the level of financial aid you receive?
FAQs.answer: Schools in this industry need to attract the optimum government support available, including grants, to offer a range of quality training at minimal cost to students.

FAQs.question: Federal funding for creative arts is expected to fall in 2022. How reliant is the school on federal government funding? Do you receive funds from any other sources?
FAQs.answer: Decreased federal funding for the creative arts reduces the amount of scholarship and program funding in the industry. This lowers demand for fine arts training by raising costs for students.

FAQs.question: The number of school-aged children affects demand for fine arts schools. Are you located in an area with a growing school-age population? How has the age distribution of your student population changed in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Growth in the number of K-12 students typically leads to an increase in enrollment at fine arts schools since many students are in this age bracket.

FAQs.question: Corporations with high profits are more likely to make charitable donations to arts and arts education. How do you intend to develop relations with various foundations or charitable trusts? How reliant is the school on donations, grants and endowments?
FAQs.answer: Corporations with high profit are more likely to make charitable donations to the arts and arts education. As corporate profit across all US industries increases, industry revenue from charitable donations increases as well.
